newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: FOCUS - Reed-Elsevier buys Disney business publisher.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS - Reed-Elsevier buys Disney business publisher.

text.p: Reed Elsevier said on Monday it was spending $447 million of its own cash to buy U.S. trade magazine publisher Chilton Business Corp from Walt Disney Co unit ABC Inc.

The Anglo-Dutch publishing group said the deal, its second major U.S. acquisition this year, would immediately contribute to its profits. Reed-Elsevier bought MDL Information Systems Inc. by the Anglo-Dutch group's scientific publishing division for $320 million earlier this year.
Chilton, based in Radnor Pennsylvania, made a pre-tax profit of $28 million in 1996 on sales of $203 million. Since 1992, it has achieved compound growth of pre-tax profits of 17 percent.
It publishes 39 business magazine titles, focusing on manufacturing, entertainment and automotive topics.
Reed-Elsevier said it would merge the core Chilton trade press business with its own U.S. business magazines unit, Cahners Publishing Co, which has a stable of over 90 titles.
Chilton's trade exhibitions unit, PEMCO, will become part of Reed Exhibitions.
Reed-Elsevier quoted its co-chairman Nigel Stapleton as saying Chilton was an ideal match for Cahners.
"Chilton fits superbly...and this acquisition offers attractive opportunities for revenue growth and operational synergies," he said.

Group strategy director Peter van Hooff told Reuters combining Chilton and Cahners, Reed-Elsevier could raise its U.S. business-to-business publishing operating profit margins to around 20 percent in 1999 from some 15 to 17 percent now.
Van Hooff said the deal would significantly strengthen Reed Elsevier's U.S. trade magazine publishing business, providing plenty of scope to raise revenues and cut costs.
"The combination of Cahners and Chilton gives us even stronger positions in more markets," he said.

Van Hooff said Reed-Elsevier would benefit from eliminating overlap between previously competing titles and making them more complementary. Avertising sales forces could be merged and combined rate cards could be offered to advertisers.

Van Hooff said Chilton's magazines would also broaden and deepen editorial content, which Reed-Elsevier could offer via electronic publishing platforms. The Chilton titles did not previously have their own electronic outlet.
"The Chilton titles will really benefit from the lead we have in electronic publishing," Van Hooff said.

Van Hooff said Reed-Elsevier, which publishes the U.S. showbusiness newspaper Variety, had already been working on plans to develop an online news and information service for the entertainment industry.
Chilton's entertainment titles would add further momentum to this project, he said.
